questions.text: All the following are known risk factors for the development of ovarian carcinoma except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Use of oral pills (Option B) is the correct answer because the use of oral contraceptives is known to decrease the risk of ovarian cancer, rather than being a risk factor. Oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) are also protective against endometrial carcinoma. All other options are recognized risk factors.
  • Ovarian carcinoma is a significant gynecological malignancy with various risk factors.
  • The average age of diagnosis is around 60 years.
  • Factors like early menarche and late menopause, low parity/infertility, and a family history of ovarian, breast, endometrial, or colorectal cancer increase the risk.
  • Specific genetic predispositions, such as BRCA1 and BRCA2 mutations, are also strong risk factors.

Explanation of Other Options:

  • Family history of ovarian carcinoma (Option A): This is a known risk factor for ovarian cancer.
  • Use of clomiphene (Option C): The use of gonadotropins/clomiphene citrate for ovulation induction is listed as a risk factor for ovarian carcinoma.
  • BRCA 1 positive individual (Option D): Being a BRCA1 positive individual is a significant genetic risk factor for ovarian carcinoma.

Key Takeaways:

  • Family history of ovarian or related cancers (breast, endometrial, colorectal) is a major risk factor for ovarian carcinoma.
  • BRCA1 and BRCA2 mutations significantly increase ovarian cancer risk.
  • Infertility and use of ovulation-inducing drugs like clomiphene are also risk factors.
  • Oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) are protective against both ovarian and endometrial cancer, reducing the risk.

questions.text: Which of the following strategies has been recommended to reduce the hereditary risk for ovarian cancer in women with BRCA-1 and BRCA-2 mutations?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Prophylactic oophorectomy (Option D) is the only proven way to prevent ovarian cancer in women with BRCA-1 and BRCA-2 mutations. This procedure, often involving bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy (BSO), is approximately 90% effective in preventing epithelial ovarian cancer in these carriers.
  • BRCA-1 and BRCA-2 are tumor suppressor genes.
  • Individuals inheriting mutations in BRCA-1 and BRCA-2 have a high susceptibility to hereditary breast or ovarian cancer.
  • These mutations are inherited in an autosomal dominant
  • Prophylactic BSO is typically performed upon completion of childbearing or at a certain age.
  • An additional benefit of prophylactic oophorectomy is a 50-80% reduction in breast cancer risk.

Explanation of Other Options:

Use of oral contraceptive pills (Option A): While the use of oral contraceptive pills is associated with a 50% decreased risk for developing ovarian cancer in BRCA-1 or BRCA-2 mutation carriers, it is not the only proven way to prevent ovarian cancer.

Screening with transvaginal ultrasound (Option B): In BRCA1- or BRCA2-mutation carriers who do not wish to undergo prophylactic surgery, transvaginal sonographic examination is part of a recommended screening regimen, but it is not a preventive strategy itself.

Screening with CA - 125 (Option C): Similar to transvaginal ultrasound, CA-125 blood testing is recommended as part of a screening combination for BRCA1- or BRCA2-mutation carriers who opt against prophylactic surgery, but it serves for detection, not prevention.

Key Takeaways:

  • Prophylactic bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy (BSO) is the most effective proven method for preventing hereditary ovarian cancer in BRCA1/2 mutation carriers.
  • OCPs offer a reduced risk but are not as effective as surgery in prevention and may carry other risks.
  • Screening with CA-125 and transvaginal ultrasound are detection strategies for those who defer surgery, not preventive measures.
  • Genetic testing is increasingly integrated into clinical practice for ovarian cancer susceptibility.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most radiosensitive ovarian tumor?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Dysgerminoma (Option A) is the most radiosensitive ovarian tumor. This characteristic makes radiotherapy an effective treatment modality for dysgerminomas.
  • Dysgerminoma is the most common malignant germ cell tumor of the ovary, accounting for about 40% of all ovarian cancers of germ cell origin.
  • It is considered the female equivalent of seminoma.
  • Dysgerminoma also has the best prognosis among germ cell tumors.
  • It has the maximum bilaterality among germ cell tumors.
  • Most common ovarian tumour (overall) - Epithelial cell tumour.
  • The most common tumour in young women is - Germ cell tumour.
  • Most common malignant tumour of ovary - Serous cystadenocarcinoma.
  • Most common benign tumour of ovary (overall) - Dermoid cyst
  • Most common benign epithelial ovary - Serous cystadenoma.
  • Most common germ cell tumour - Mature teratoma (Dermoid cyst).
  • Most common malignant GCT - Dysgerminoma.
  • Most common ovarian tumour in pregnancy (but it remains undiagnosed) - Serous cystadenoma.
  • Most Common benign tumour diagnosed in pregnancy - Dermoid cyst.
  • Overall most common ovarian tumour diagnosed in pregnancy - Dermoid cyst.
  • Most common malignant ovarian tumor detected during pregnancy - Dysgerminoma.
  • Germ cell Tumor with best prognosis Dysgerminoma
  • Germ cell tumor with worst prognosis- endodermal sinus tumor
  • Germ cell tumor which has maximum bilaterality- Dysgerminoma
  • Germ cell tumor which presents as acute abdomen- Endodermal Sinus Tumor
  • Most common ovarian tumour to undergo torsion during pregnancy - Dermoid cyst.
  • Most common ovarian tumours involve the opposite ovary by metastasis - Granulosa cell tumour.
  • Most radiosensitive ovarian tumour – Dysgerminoma.
  • Most rapidly growing ovarian tumour - Yolk sac Tm- (Endodermal Sinus Tumor)
  • Most connective tissue tumors - Fibroma.

Explanation of Other Options:

  • Dermoid cyst (Option B): Also known as a mature teratoma, a dermoid cyst is the most common benign germ cell tumor of the ovary. It is benign and generally not radiosensitive in the context of cancer treatment.
  • Serous cystadenoma (Option C): This is the most common benign epithelial ovarian tumor. As a benign tumor, it is not treated with radiotherapy for malignancy.
  • Endodermal sinus tumour (Option D): Also known as Yolk sac tumor, this germ cell tumor has the worst prognosis and is the most rapidly growing ovarian tumor. While malignant, it is not as radiosensitive as dysgerminoma; its treatment primarily involves chemotherapy.

Key Takeaways:

  • Dysgerminoma is the most radiosensitive ovarian tumor.
  • It is the most common malignant germ cell tumor of the ovary.
  • Dermoid cysts are the most common benign germ cell tumors.
  • Serous cystadenoma is the most common benign epithelial ovarian tumor.
  • Endodermal sinus tumor has the worst prognosis and is very rapidly growing.

choices.text: 10% of all epithelial tumours are borderline.

questions.text: All of the following are true about Borderline tumors except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Metastases are common (Option C) is the exception, meaning it is a false statement about borderline tumors.
  • While borderline tumors can spread, especially within the peritoneal cavity (implants), true destructive metastases are uncommon. Their behavior is typically indolent, distinguishing them from invasive carcinomas where destructive metastases are characteristic.
  • Borderline tumors represent an intermediate category between benign and malignant epithelial ovarian tumors.
  • They account for approximately 10% of all epithelial ovarian tumors.
  • A key histological feature is the absence of stromal invasion, which differentiates them from invasive carcinomas.

Explanation of Other Options:

10% of all epithelial tumours are borderline (Option A): This is a true statement. Borderline tumors constitute about 10% of all epithelial ovarian tumors.

They have a good prognosis (Option B): This is a true statement. Borderline tumors are characterized by a good prognosis, with high survival rates even when they spread (as non-invasive implants).

Absence of stromal invasion (Option D): This is a true statement. A defining characteristic of borderline tumors, distinguishing them from invasive carcinoma, is the absence of stromal invasion.

Key Takeaways:

  • Borderline ovarian tumors are an intermediate category of epithelial ovarian tumors, making up about 10% of them.
  • Their defining histological feature is the absence of stromal invasion.
  • They generally have a good prognosis.
  • While they can have peritoneal implants, true destructive metastases are uncommon.

questions.text: According to WHO classification of ovarian tumours, Brenner tumor of ovary belongs to:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Epithelial tumours (A) is the correct classification. The World Health Organization (WHO) classifies ovarian tumors into several categories. Brenner tumor of the ovary is specifically categorized under Epithelial tumors. These tumors arise from the surface epithelium of the ovary.

Explanation of Other Options:

Sex cord stromal tumours (Option B): This category includes tumors arising from the ovarian stroma and sex cords, such as granulosa cell tumors and Sertoli-Leydig cell tumors. Brenner tumors do not originate from these cells.

Germ cell tumours (Option C): These tumors originate from the primordial germ cells of the ovary. Examples include dysgerminomas, teratomas, and yolk sac tumors. Brenner tumors are not derived from germ cells.

Metastatic tumours (Option D): These are cancers that have spread to the ovary from another primary site in the body, such as the gastrointestinal tract (Krukenberg tumor), breast, or lung. Brenner tumors are primary ovarian tumors, not metastatic ones.

Key Takeaways:

  • The WHO classification system for ovarian tumors categorizes them based on their cell of origin.
  • Brenner tumor is a type of epithelial ovarian tumor.

questions.text: Chemotherapeutic drug effective in the treatment of epithelial ovarian cancer is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

a and b both (D) is the correct answer. Both Carboplatin (A) and Paclitaxel (B) are highly effective chemotherapeutic drugs commonly used in the treatment of epithelial ovarian cancer.

Explanation of Other Options:

Carboplatin (Option A): Carboplatin is a platinum-based chemotherapy drug that is a cornerstone in the treatment of epithelial ovarian cancer, often used in combination regimens.

Paclitaxel (Option B): Paclitaxel is a taxane-class chemotherapy drug that is also widely used in combination with platinum-based drugs for epithelial ovarian cancer.

Cyclophosphamide (Option C): Cyclophosphamide is an alkylating agent. While it has a role in some cancer treatments, it is not the primary or most effective frontline chemotherapy agent for epithelial ovarian cancer compared to the platinum-taxane combination.

Explanation:

D) B & C is the correct answer because both statements B) "Resembles fibroma" and C) "Common in postmenopausal age group" accurately describe characteristics of Brenner tumors.

  • This epithelial neoplasm grossly resembles an ovarian fibroma.
  • Predominantly seen in postmenopausal women (around menopause).
  • Generally unilateral, affecting only one ovary.(Option A ruled out)
  • Mostly benign, with very rare malignant change.
  • Histology: Characterized by Walthard cell rests and cells with "coffee bean" nuclei.
  • Can cause menopausal bleeding and may be associated with Pseudo Meigs syndrome.

Key Takeaways:

  • Brenner tumor is a benign epithelial tumor often seen in postmenopausal women.
  • It resembles fibroma and is typically unilateral.

questions.text: A 25-year-old married nullipara undergoes laparoscopic cystectomy for ovarian cyst which on histopathology reveals ovarian serous cystadenocarcinoma. What should be the next management?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Serial Ca-125 measurement and follow-up is the most appropriate next management step for this patient.

  • Given that she is a young (25-year-old) nullipara with an ovarian serous cystadenocarcinoma that was likely removed via laparoscopic cystectomy, it is presumed to be an early-stage (likely Stage Ia), low-grade tumor.
  • In such cases, particularly when fertility preservation is desired, the primary goal is to preserve the uterus and contralateral ovary.
  • Therefore, follow-up with routine periodic pelvic examinations and serum CA-125 levels is the recommended course of action, with the understanding that the other ovary and uterus might be removed after childbearing completion.

Explanation of Other Options:

Hysterectomy and bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy (Option B): This radical surgical approach involves removing the uterus, fallopian tubes, and both ovaries. While it is standard treatment for advanced ovarian cancer, it would preclude future childbearing and is not indicated as the immediate next step for early-stage disease in a young nullipara desiring fertility preservation.

Hysterectomy + Radiotherapy (Option C): Radiotherapy is generally not the primary treatment modality for ovarian serous cystadenocarcinoma, especially in early stages. Combining it with hysterectomy would again be overly aggressive for fertility preservation and not standard first-line management.

Radiotherapy (Option D): Radiotherapy alone is not the definitive treatment for ovarian cancer and is typically reserved for specific situations like palliation or targeting residual disease in localized areas, not as a primary management strategy post-cystectomy for presumed early-stage disease.

Key Takeaways:

  • In early-stage (e.g., Stage Ia, Grade 1-2) ovarian cancer in young women desiring fertility, fertility-sparing surgery (e.g., unilateral oophorectomy or cystectomy) is a viable option.
  • Serial CA-125 measurements and regular follow-up are crucial for monitoring these patients to detect any recurrence.

Explanation:

B) "It secretes hormones" and C) "Associated with endometrial hyperplasia" are true characteristics of granulosa cell tumors.

Granulosa cell tumour is a sex cord tumour.

  • Age: It can be seen at any age. Most common before puberty and after 40 years.
  • Tumour secretes estrogen which is responsible for clinical features like precocious puberty, menometrorrhagia and post menopausal bleeding.
  • They are low grade malignancies.
  • Almost always unilateral(B/L in < 2%) i.e. option d incorrect
  • Since they secrete estrogen, 25-50% are associated with Endometrial hyperplasia.
  • 5 percent of tumours are associated with endometrial cancer.
  • Marker: Granulosa cell tumour secrete inhibin which is a useful marker for it.
  • Prognosis: Is good with 5 year survival rate being 90%.
  • Metastasis: It is peculiar in case of granulosa cell tumour, it first involves opposite ovary followed by metastasis in lumbar region.
  • Surgery is the treatment of choice for granulosa cell tumors, with the type of surgery depending on the patient's age and reproductive status. Children and women of reproductive age - Postmenopausal women Unilateral salpingo-oophorectomy TAH + BSO is preferred.
  • It's important to note that adjuvant chemotherapy has no proven benefit in preventing recurrence of this disease.

Explanation of Other Options:

MC malignant tumour of ovary (Option A): The most common malignant tumor of the ovary is Serous cystadenocarcinoma.

Key Takeaways:

  • Granulosa cell tumors are estrogen-secreting and frequently linked to endometrial hyperplasia.
  • Surgery is the primary treatment, and adjuvant chemotherapy is not beneficial in preventing recurrence.

questions.text: Malignant germ cell tumours of ovary includes:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Choriocarcinoma is correctly identified as a malignant germ cell tumor of the ovary. Germ cell tumors are a diverse group of ovarian neoplasms that arise from germ cells and can be benign or malignant. Malignant germ cell tumors often grow rapidly and are characterized by subacute pelvic pain.

  • Germ cell Tumors of ovary: Mnemonic: YES PCT
    • Y- Yolk sac Tumor (Endodermal sinus Tm)
    • E- Embryonal carcinoma
    • S- Seminoma ≈ Dysgerminoma
    • P- Polyembryoma
    • C- Choriocarcinoma
    • T- Teratoma ≈ Dermoid.
  • The most common germ cell tumor is the Mature teratoma or Dermoid cyst, which is benign in nature.
  • The most common malignant germ cell tumor is Dysgerminoma.
  • The second most common malignant germ cell tumor is the Endodermal sinus Tumor (Yolk Sac tumor).
  • Most common benign tumor of the ovary is a Dermoid cyst.

Explanation of Other Options:

Arrhenoblastoma (Option B): This is not a germ cell tumor; it is a sex cord-stromal tumor of the ovary.

Brenner's tumor (Option C): This is not a germ cell tumor; it is a type of epithelial ovarian tumor, typically benign.

Serous cystadenoma (Option D): This is not a germ cell tumor; it is a common type of epithelial ovarian tumor, typically benign.

Key Takeaways:

  • Germ cell tumors of the ovary originate from germ cells and can be malignant, such as choriocarcinoma.
  • Distinguish germ cell tumors from other ovarian tumor types like sex cord-stromal and epithelial tumors.

questions.text: True about dysgerminoma of ovary except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Dysgerminoma does not typically secrete alpha-fetoprotein (AFP); therefore, an increase in AFP is not characteristic of this tumor. Instead, dysgerminomas are known to secrete LDH and placental alkaline phosphatase, which serve as their tumor markers.

  • Dysgerminoma is the commonest malignant germ cell tumor of the ovary and is the most common ovarian malignancy detected during pregnancy.
  • It primarily affects young women (average age of incidence is 20 years) and not postmenopausal females.
  • It is usually unilateral, but it is the only germ cell malignancy with a significant rate of bilateral ovarian involvement- 15 to 20% .
  • Pathologically, it is a solid neoplasm with areas of softening due to degeneration.
  • Unlike other germ cell tumors, dysgerminoma does not secrete AFP and HCG is only rarely secreted.
  • It secretes LDH and placental alkaline phosphatase, which are used as tumor markers of dysgerminoma.
  • The most common route of spread is via lymphatics but hematogenous (blood) and direct spread are also seen.
  • Dysgerminoma is the most radiosensitive tumor.
  • The treatment of choice is surgery (unilateral salpingo-oophorectomy) along with proper surgical staging followed by Bleomycin, Etoposide, and Cisplatin (BEP) based chemotherapy to preserve fertility.
  • Chemotherapy is helpful in metastatic spread.
  • They have the best prognosis of all malignant ovarian germ cell variants.
  • The recurrence rate is high.

Explanation of Other Options:

Blood spread seen (Option A): While the most common route of spread is via lymphatics, hematogenous (blood) spread is also seen.

Radiosensitive (Option B): Dysgerminoma is 'the most radiosensitive tumor' among ovarian tumors.

Bleomycin, etoposide and cisplatin given (Option D): Bleomycin, Etoposide, and Cisplatin (BEP) based chemotherapy is given for dysgerminoma, especially 'for metastatic spread' or after surgery to preserve fertility'.

Key Takeaways:

  • Dysgerminoma is the most common malignant germ cell tumor of the ovary, often affecting young women and is highly radiosensitive.
  • Its tumor markers are LDH and placental alkaline phosphatase, not AFP.

questions.text: True about dermoid cyst of ovary are all except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Dermoid cysts are benign teratomas and do not invariably turn to malignancy. While malignant transformation can occur, it is rare. They are the most common benign tumor of the ovary and are the commonest tumor to undergo torsion.

  • A dermoid cyst is a benign teratoma.
  • It is the most common benign tumor of the ovary in the reproductive age group.
  • It is also the most common benign neoplasm diagnosed during pregnancy.
  • Dermoid cysts are the most common germ cell tumor.
  • They are the commonest tumor to undergo torsion.
  • Characteristically, they are unilocular cysts containing hair and cheesy sebaceous material, teeth, bones, thyroid tissue, and cartilage.
  • If teeth or bones are seen in X-ray in an adnexal mass, this finding is pathognomonic for teratoma, and thus X-rays are diagnostic.

Explanation of Other Options:

It is teratoma (Option A): A dermoid cyst is explicitly defined as a benign teratoma.

Frequently undergo torsion (Option B): Dermoid cysts are the commonest tumor to undergo torsion.

X-ray is diagnostic (Option C): The presence of teeth or bones in an X-ray of an adnexal mass is pathognomonic for teratoma, making X-ray a diagnostic tool.

Key Takeaways:

  • Dermoid cysts are common, benign ovarian tumors originating from germ cells, known for their characteristic contents and propensity for torsion.
  • While a type of teratoma, they are benign and rarely undergo malignant transformation.

choices.text: It is seen in young individuals

questions.text: True about endodermal sinus tumors except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Endodermal sinus tumors, also known as yolk sac tumors, are characterized by elevated AFP and Alpha 1 antitrypsin, not elevated HCG. They are highly malignant tumors and are the third most common malignant germ cell tumor of the ovary.

  • Endodermal sinus (yolk sac) tumors affect mostly children or young women (age group 14-20 years).
  • The tumor is highly malignant and is the most rapidly growing tumor of the whole body.
  • Histologically, the pathognomonic finding is Schiller-Duval bodies, which is a single papilla lined by tumor cells with a central blood vessel.
  • Due to the high rate of growth, the tumor usually presents with an acute abdomen.
  • It is unilateral in 100% of cases, therefore biopsy of the opposite ovary is contraindicated.
  • Almost all cases are associated with raised AFP and Alpha 1 antitrypsin.
  • It is the most deadly malignant ovarian germ cell tumor.
  • Treatment involves chemotherapy.
  • It has a high propensity for rapid growth, peritoneal spread, and distant hematogenous dissemination to the lungs.

Explanation of Other Options:

Schiller duval bodies seen (Option A): Schiller-Duval bodies are the pathognomonic histological finding in endodermal sinus tumors.

It is a malignant tumour (Option B): Endodermal sinus tumors are highly malignant and are considered the most deadly malignant ovarian germ cell tumor.

It is seen in young individuals (Option D): These tumors mostly affect children or young women (age group 14-20 years).

Key Takeaways:

  • Endodermal sinus tumors are highly malignant germ cell tumors primarily affecting young individuals.
  • They are characterized by the presence of Schiller-Duval bodies and elevated AFP, not HCG.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman, Smt. Pushpa, undergoes exploratory laparotomy for evaluation of an adnexal mass noted on imaging. Intraoperatively, both ovaries are found to be symmetrically enlarged, with smooth outer surfaces. Histopathology is pending. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Krukenberg tumors are characteristically bilaterally enlarged ovaries with a smooth surface, which matches the description in the clinical scenario.

  • Krukenberg tumors arise by retrograde lymphatic spread, where carcinoma cells pass from the stomach to the superior gastric lymph node, which also receives lymphatics from the ovary.
  • Krukenberg tumor is generally a metastatic tumor to the ovary. But "krukenberg tumor may be a primary tumor
  • Characteristics of Krukenberg Tumor include:
    • Always bilateral
    • Have a smooth surface
    • No tendency to form adhesions
    • Freely mobile
    • No infiltration through the capsule.
  • Histologically, the tumor has signet ring cells in the background of a myxomatous stroma.
  • They retain the shape of a normal ovary.
  • Have a waxy consistency.

Explanation of Other Options:

Granulosa cell tumor (Option A): Granulosa cell tumors are sex cord-stromal tumors, not typically characterized by bilateral smooth surface enlargement due to metastatic spread from the stomach. They can be unilateral or bilateral, but their origin and typical presentation differ.

Dysgerminoma (Option C): Dysgerminomas are malignant germ cell tumors. While they can be bilateral (15-20%), the "smooth surface" described is more indicative of metastatic tumors like Krukenberg, which often retain the ovarian shape. Dysgerminomas are solid tumors.

Primary adenocarcinoma (Option D): While primary ovarian adenocarcinomas can be bilateral, they often present with papillary surface growths, ascites, and a tendency to adhere to surrounding structures, which contrasts with the smooth surface and free mobility of Krukenberg tumors.

Key Takeaways:

  • Krukenberg tumors are metastatic ovarian tumors, most commonly from the stomach, characterized by bilateral, enlarged ovaries with a smooth surface and free mobility.
  • The presence of signet ring cells histologically is a hallmark of Krukenberg tumors.

questions.text: The following tumours commonly metastasise to the ovary, except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

While stomach, malignant melanoma, and lymphoma are known to commonly metastasize to the ovary, esophageal cancer is generally not among the common primary sites that metastasize to the ovary. Approximately 5-6% of ovarian tumors are metastatic from other organs.

  • Stomach is a very common primary site for ovarian metastasis, notably leading to Krukenberg tumors.(Option B ruled out)
  • Malignant melanoma can also metastasize to the ovary. (Option A ruled out)
  • Lymphoma can involve the ovary as a site of metastasis or primary involvement.(Option D ruled out)
  • Common primary sites that metastasize to the ovary include the gastrointestinal tract (stomach, colon, appendix), breast, and less commonly, malignant melanoma and lymphoma.

Key Takeaways:

  • While several cancers can metastasize to the ovary, primary tumors from the stomach, breast, colon, and malignant melanoma are among the most common sources.
  • Esophageal cancer is generally not considered a common source of ovarian metastasis.

questions.text: A 55-year-old female presents with abdominal pain, distension, ascites and dyspnea. Her CA 125 levels are elevated. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The patient's presentation with abdominal pain, distension, ascites, dyspnea, and elevated CA 125 levels in a 55-year-old female strongly suggests ovarian cancer. The most common age incidence for primary ovarian neoplasms is 40-60 years, with a peak age incidence being 55-60 years. The symptoms described are classic for advanced ovarian malignancy, and elevated CA 125 levels favor the diagnosis of ovarian cancer given the clinical picture.

  • Ovarian malignancies generally present with vague symptoms like abdominal pain and dyspepsia.
  • Patients may also experience irregular menses.
  • If a pelvic mass compresses the bladder or rectum, the patient may have urinary frequency or constipation.
  • In advanced stages, patients commonly have symptoms related to the presence of ascites, omental metastasis, or bowel metastasis, such as abdominal distension, dyspnea, bloating, nausea, anorexia, or early satiety.
  • The most important sign of epithelial ovarian cancer is the presence of a pelvic mass on physical examination.
  • For postmenopausal patients with an adnexal mass and a very high serum CA125 level (>200U/ml), there is a 96% positive predictive value for ovarian malignancy.

Explanation of Other Options:

Ca cervix (Option B): Cervical cancer typically presents with abnormal vaginal bleeding or post-coital bleeding and is not usually associated with elevated CA 125 or significant ascites in its primary presentation.

Ca lung (Option C): Lung cancer primarily causes respiratory symptoms like cough, hemoptysis, and shortness of breath. While it can metastasize and cause ascites, it is not the most likely diagnosis given the typical presentation and the specific elevation of CA 125, which is more indicative of ovarian cancer in this context.

Lymphoma (Option D): Lymphoma (a type of cancer affecting lymphocytes) could present with abdominal symptoms, but CA 125 is not its primary marker, and the overall clinical picture strongly points to ovarian cancer.

Key Takeaways:

  • Ovarian cancer often presents with vague abdominal symptoms in its early stages, progressing to ascites and respiratory symptoms in advanced disease, particularly in postmenopausal women.
  • Elevated CA 125 levels in conjunction with these symptoms are highly suggestive of ovarian malignancy.

questions.text: Pain of ovarian carcinoma is referred to:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Ovarian pain is referred to along the medial side of the thigh.
  • This occurs because the obturator nerve, during its course, runs in front of the internal iliac vessels and is separated from the normally situated ovary by only the parietal peritoneum lining the pelvic wall.
  • Thus, pain from the ovary may be referred along the nerve to the skin on the medial side of the thigh.
  • Simpson Pain refers to colicky pain in patients with Ca Endometrium.
  • Simpson Pain is referred to the hypogastrium or to both iliac fossae.
  • It is not severe and tends to appear at the same time each day lasting only 1-2 hours.

Explanation of Other Options:

Back of thigh (Option A): Pain referred to the back of the thigh is typically associated with sciatic nerve irritation or issues in the posterior thigh muscles, not ovarian pain.

Cervical region (Option B): Pain in the cervical region is related to the neck and upper spine, not directly to ovarian pathology.

Anterior surface of thigh (Option C): Pain referred to the anterior surface of the thigh is often associated with the femoral nerve or issues in the anterior thigh muscles, not typically ovarian pain.

Key Takeaways:

  • Ovarian pain can be referred along the obturator nerve to the medial side of the thigh.
  • This referred pain mechanism is due to the anatomical proximity of the ovary to the obturator nerve.

Explanation:

Meigs syndrome is specifically defined as the triad of ascites and right-sided hydrothorax associated with an ovarian fibroma. This syndrome is relatively rare, occurring in less than 5% of fibromas. Both ascites and hydrothorax resolve spontaneously after removal of the tumor.

  • Ascites is caused by transudation of fluid from the ovarian fibroma.
  • Hydrothorax develops secondary to the flow of ascitic fluid into the pleural space via lymphatics of the diaphragm.
  • Ascites occur in approximately 50% of cases when the tumor size is > 6 cm.
  • Tumors producing Meigs syndrome manifest in the late childbearing period, i.e., 30-40 years.
  • Criteria for diagnosis of True Meigs syndrome include:
    • The tumor must be ovarian, solid, and benign.
    • Both hydrothorax and ascites must be present.
    • Removal of the tumor must result in their spontaneous and permanent cure.
  • Pseudo Meigs syndrome can be seen in association with other benign or malignant tumors, such as Brenner's tumor and Granulosa cell tumor. In these cases, hydrothorax could also be a manifestation of pulmonary metastasis.

Explanation of Other Options:

Teratoma (Option A): While teratomas are ovarian tumors, Meigs syndrome is not primarily associated with teratomas. Pseudo Meigs syndrome can, however, be associated with mature teratomas.

Brenner tumour (Option B): Brenner tumors can be associated with Pseudo Meigs syndrome, but not True Meigs syndrome.

Theca cell tumour (Option C): Theca cell tumors (thecomas) can also be associated with Pseudo Meigs syndrome, but True Meigs syndrome is specifically linked to fibroma.

Key Takeaways:

  • Meigs syndrome is a specific triad of ovarian fibroma, ascites, and hydrothorax, which resolves after tumor removal.
  • Pseudo Meigs syndrome involves similar effusions but is associated with other benign or malignant ovarian tumors, including Brenner and granulosa cell tumors, or even non-ovarian pelvic tumors.
